qas.question: GABA is the abbreviation for what?
Which of two neurotransmitters is usually inhibitory?
The neurostransmitter that usually excites targets is called what?
Tranquilizers affect which of the two common neurotransmitters?

context: The two neurotransmitters that are used most widely in the vertebrate brain are <a2_0>glutamate,<a2_0/> which almost always exerts excitatory effects on target neurons, and <a0_0><a1_0><a3_0>gamma-aminobutyric acid<a0_0/> (GABA)<a3_0/><a1_0/>, which is almost always inhibitory. Neurons using these transmitters can be found in nearly every part of the brain. Because of their ubiquity, drugs that act on glutamate or GABA tend to have broad and powerful effects. Some general anesthetics act by reducing the effects of glutamate; most tranquilizers exert their sedative effects by enhancing the effects of GABA.
